carry't, he will carry't; 'tis in his buttons; he
will carry't.

linegroup.speaker: PAGE
linegroup.line: Not by my consent, I promise you. The gentleman is
of no having: he kept company with the wild prince
and Poins; he is of too high a region; he knows too
much. No, he shall not knit a knot in his fortunes
with the finger of my substance: if he take her,
let him take her simply; the wealth I have waits on
my consent, and my consent goes not that way.

linegroup.speaker: FORD
linegroup.line: I beseech you heartily, some of you go home with me
to dinner: besides your cheer, you shall have
sport; I will show you a monster. Master doctor,
you shall go; so shall you, Master Page; and you, Sir Hugh.

linegroup.speaker: SHALLOW
linegroup.line: Well, fare you well: we shall have the freer wooing
at Master Page's.

linegroup.speaker: DOCTOR CAIUS
linegroup.line: Go home, John Rugby; I come anon.

linegroup.speaker: Host
linegroup.line: Farewell, my hearts: I will to my honest knight
Falstaff, and drink canary with him.

linegroup.speaker: FORD
linegroup.line: Aside I think I shall drink in pipe wine first
with him; I'll make him dance. Will you go, gentles?

linegroup.speaker: All
linegroup.line: Have with you to see this monster.

section.title: SCENE III. A room in FORD'S house.
section.para: Enter MISTRESS FORD and MISTRESS PAGE

linegroup.speaker: MISTRESS FORD
linegroup.line: What, John! What, Robert!

linegroup.speaker: MISTRESS PAGE
linegroup.line: Quickly, quickly! is the buck-basket--

linegroup.speaker: MISTRESS FORD
linegroup.line: I warrant. What, Robin, I say!

linegroup.speaker: MISTRESS PAGE
linegroup.line: Come, come, come.

linegroup.speaker: MISTRESS FORD
linegroup.line: Here, set it down.

linegroup.speaker: MISTRESS PAGE
linegroup.line: Give your men the charge; we must be brief.

linegroup.speaker: MISTRESS FORD
linegroup.line: Marry, as I told you before, John and Robert, be
ready here hard by in the brew-house: and when I
suddenly call you, come forth, and without any pause
or staggering take this basket on your shoulders:
that done, trudge with it in all haste, and carry
it among the whitsters in Datchet-mead, and there
empty it in the muddy ditch close by the Thames side.

linegroup.speaker: MISTRESS PAGE
linegroup.line: You will do it?

linegroup.speaker: MISTRESS FORD
linegroup.line: I ha' told them over and over; they lack no
direction. Be gone, and come when you are called.

linegroup.speaker: MISTRESS PAGE
linegroup.line: Here comes little Robin.

linegroup.speaker: MISTRESS FORD
linegroup.line: How now, my eyas-musket! what news with you?

linegroup.speaker: ROBIN
linegroup.line: My master, Sir John, is come in at your back-door,
Mistress Ford, and requests your company.

linegroup.speaker: MISTRESS PAGE
linegroup.line: You little Jack-a-Lent, have you been true to us?

linegroup.speaker: ROBIN
linegroup.line: Ay, I'll be sworn. My master knows not of your
being here and hath threatened to put me into
everlasting liberty if I tell you of it; for he
swears he'll turn me away.

linegroup.speaker: MISTRESS PAGE
linegroup.line: Thou'rt a good boy: this secrecy of thine shall be
a tailor to thee and shall make thee a new doublet
and hose. I'll go hide me.

linegroup.speaker: MISTRESS FORD
linegroup.line: Do so. Go tell thy master I am alone.
Mistress Page, remember you your cue.

linegroup.speaker: MISTRESS PAGE
linegroup.line: I warrant thee; if I do not act it, hiss me.

linegroup.speaker: MISTRESS FORD
linegroup.line: Go to, then: we'll use this unwholesome humidity,
this gross watery pumpion; we'll teach him to know
turtles from jays.

linegroup.speaker: FALSTAFF
linegroup.line: Have I caught thee, my heavenly jewel? Why, now let
me die, for I have lived long enough: this is the
period of my ambition: O this blessed hour!

linegroup.speaker: MISTRESS FORD
linegroup.line: O sweet Sir John!

linegroup.speaker: FALSTAFF
linegroup.line: Mistress Ford, I cannot cog, I cannot prate,
Mistress Ford. Now shall I sin in my wish: I would
thy husband were dead: I'll speak it before the
best lord; I would make thee my lady.

linegroup.speaker: MISTRESS FORD
linegroup.line: I your lady, Sir John! alas, I should be a pitiful lady!

linegroup.speaker: FALSTAFF
linegroup.line: Let the court of France show me such another. I see
how thine eye would emulate the diamond: thou hast
the right arched beauty of the brow that becomes the
ship-tire, the tire-valiant, or any tire of
Venetian admittance.

linegroup.speaker: MISTRESS FORD
linegroup.line: A plain kerchief, Sir John: my brows become nothing
else; nor that well neither.

linegroup.speaker: FALSTAFF
linegroup.line: By the Lord, thou art a traitor to say so: thou
wouldst make an absolute courtier; and the firm
fixture of thy foot would give an excellent motion
to thy gait in a semi-circled farthingale. I see
what thou wert, if Fortune thy foe were not, Nature
thy friend. Come, thou canst not hide it.

linegroup.speaker: MISTRESS FORD
linegroup.line: Believe me, there is no such thing in me.

linegroup.speaker: FALSTAFF
linegroup.line: What made me love thee? let that persuade thee
there's something extraordinary in thee. Come, I
cannot cog and say thou art this and that, like a
many of these lisping hawthorn-buds, that come like
women in men's apparel, and smell like Bucklersbury
in simple time; I cannot: but I love thee; none
but thee; and thou deservest it.

linegroup.speaker: MISTRESS FORD
linegroup.line: Do not betray me, sir. I fear you love Mistress Page.

linegroup.speaker: FALSTAFF
linegroup.line: Thou mightst as well say I love to walk by the
Counter-gate, which is as hateful to me as the reek
of a lime-kiln.

linegroup.speaker: MISTRESS FORD
linegroup.line: Well, heaven knows how I love you; and you shall one
day find it.

linegroup.speaker: FALSTAFF
linegroup.line: Keep in that mind; I'll deserve it.

linegroup.speaker: MISTRESS FORD
linegroup.line: Nay, I must tell you, so you do; or else I could not
be in that mind.

linegroup.speaker: ROBIN
linegroup.line: Within Mistress Ford, Mistress Ford! here's
Mistress Page at the door, sweating and blowing and
looking wildly, and would needs speak with you presently.

linegroup.speaker: FALSTAFF
linegroup.line: She shall not see me: I will ensconce me behind the arras.

linegroup.speaker: MISTRESS FORD
linegroup.line: Pray you, do so: she's a very tattling woman.
What's the matter? how now!

linegroup.speaker: MISTRESS PAGE
linegroup.line: O Mistress Ford, what have you done? You're shamed,
you're overthrown, you're undone for ever!

linegroup.speaker: MISTRESS FORD
linegroup.line: What's the matter, good Mistress Page?

linegroup.speaker: MISTRESS PAGE
linegroup.line: O well-a-day, Mistress Ford! having an honest man
to your husband, to give him such cause of suspicion!

linegroup.speaker: MISTRESS FORD
linegroup.line: What cause of suspicion?

linegroup.speaker: MISTRESS PAGE
linegroup.line: What cause of suspicion! Out pon you! how am I
mistook in you!

linegroup.speaker: MISTRESS FORD
linegroup.line: Why, alas, what's the matter?

linegroup.speaker: MISTRESS PAGE
linegroup.line: Your husband's coming hither, woman, with all the
officers in Windsor, to search for a gentleman that
he says is here now in the house by your consent, to
take an ill advantage of his assence: you are undone.

linegroup.speaker: MISTRESS FORD
linegroup.line: 'Tis not so, I hope.

linegroup.speaker: MISTRESS PAGE
linegroup.line: Pray heaven it be not so, that you have such a man
here! but 'tis most certain your husband's coming,
with half Windsor at his heels, to search for such a
one. I come before to tell you. If you know
yourself clear, why, I am glad of it; but if you
have a friend here convey, convey him out. Be not
amazed; call all your senses to you; defend your
reputation, or bid farewell to your good life for ever.

linegroup.speaker: MISTRESS FORD
linegroup.line: What shall I do? There is a gentleman my dear
friend; and I fear not mine own shame so much as his
peril: I had rather than a thousand pound he were
out of the house.

linegroup.speaker: MISTRESS PAGE
linegroup.line: For shame! never stand 'you had rather' and 'you
had rather:' your husband's here at hand, bethink
you of some conveyance: in the house you cannot
hide him. O, how have you deceived me! Look, here
is a basket: if he be of any reasonable stature, he
may creep in here; and throw foul linen upon him, as
if it were going to bucking: or--it is whiting-time
--send him by your two men to Datchet-mead.

linegroup.speaker: MISTRESS FORD
linegroup.line: He's too big to go in there. What shall I do?

linegroup.speaker: FALSTAFF
linegroup.line: Coming forward Let me see't, let me see't, O, let
me see't! I'll in, I'll in. Follow your friend's
counsel. I'll in.

linegroup.speaker: MISTRESS PAGE
linegroup.line: What, Sir John Falstaff! Are these your letters, knight?

linegroup.speaker: FALSTAFF
linegroup.line: I love thee. Help me away. Let me creep in here.
I'll never--

section.para: Gets into the basket; they cover him with foul linen

linegroup.speaker: MISTRESS PAGE
linegroup.line: Help to cover your master, boy. Call your men,
Mistress Ford. You dissembling knight!

linegroup.speaker: MISTRESS FORD
linegroup.line: What, John! Robert! John!
Go take up these clothes here quickly. Where's the
cowl-staff? look, how you drumble! Carry them to
the laundress in Datchet-meat; quickly, come.

section.para: Enter FORD, PAGE, DOCTOR CAIUS, and SIR HUGH EVANS

linegroup.speaker: FORD
linegroup.line: Pray you, come near: if I suspect without cause,
why then make sport at me; then let me be your jest;
I deserve it. How now! whither bear you this?

linegroup.speaker: Servant
linegroup.line: To the laundress, forsooth.

linegroup.speaker: MISTRESS FORD
linegroup.line: Why, what have you to do whither they bear it? You
were best meddle with buck-washing.

linegroup.speaker: FORD
linegroup.line: Buck! I would I could wash myself of the buck!
Buck, buck, buck! Ay, buck; I warrant you, buck;
and of the season too, it shall appear.
Gentlemen, I have dreamed to-night; I'll tell you my
dream. Here, here, here be my keys: ascend my
chambers; search, seek, find out: I'll warrant
we'll unkennel the fox. Let me stop this way first.
So, now uncape.

linegroup.speaker: PAGE
linegroup.line: Good Master Ford, be contented: you wrong yourself too much.

linegroup.speaker: FORD
linegroup.line: True, Master Page. Up, gentlemen: you shall see
sport anon: follow me, gentlemen.

linegroup.speaker: SIR HUGH EVANS
linegroup.line: This is fery fantastical humours and jealousies.

linegroup.speaker: DOCTOR CAIUS
linegroup.line: By gar, 'tis no the fashion of France; it is not
jealous in France.

linegroup.speaker: PAGE
linegroup.line: Nay, follow him, gentlemen; see the issue of his search.

section.para: Exeunt PAGE, DOCTOR CAIUS, and SIR HUGH EVANS

linegroup.speaker: MISTRESS PAGE
linegroup.line: Is there not a double excellency in this?

linegroup.speaker: MISTRESS FORD
linegroup.line: I know not which pleases me better, that my husband
is deceived, or Sir John.

linegroup.speaker: MISTRESS PAGE
linegroup.line: What a taking was he in when your husband asked who
was in the basket!

linegroup.speaker: MISTRESS FORD
linegroup.line: I am half afraid he will have need of washing; so
throwing him into the water will do him a benefit.

linegroup.speaker: MISTRESS PAGE
linegroup.line: Hang him, dishonest rascal! I would all of the same
strain were in the same distress.

linegroup.speaker: MISTRESS FORD
linegroup.line: I think my husband hath some special suspicion of
Falstaff's being here; for I never saw him so gross
in his jealousy till now.

linegroup.speaker: MISTRESS PAGE
linegroup.line: I will lay a plot to try that; and we will yet have
more tricks with Falstaff: his dissolute disease will
scarce obey this medicine.

linegroup.speaker: MISTRESS FORD
linegroup.line: Shall we send that foolish carrion, Mistress
Quickly, to him, and excuse his throwing into the
water; and give him another hope, to betray him to
another punishment?

linegroup.speaker: MISTRESS PAGE
linegroup.line: We will do it: let him be sent for to-morrow,
eight o'clock, to have amends.

section.para: Re-enter FORD, PAGE, DOCTOR CAIUS, and SIR HUGH EVANS

linegroup.speaker: FORD
linegroup.line: I cannot find him: may be the knave bragged of that
he could not compass.

linegroup.speaker: MISTRESS PAGE
linegroup.line: Aside to MISTRESS FORD Heard you that?

linegroup.speaker: MISTRESS FORD
linegroup.line: You use me well, Master Ford, do you?

linegroup.speaker: FORD
linegroup.line: Ay, I do so.

linegroup.speaker: MISTRESS FORD
linegroup.line: Heaven make you better than your thoughts!

linegroup.speaker: FORD
linegroup.line: Amen!

linegroup.speaker: MISTRESS PAGE
linegroup.line: You do yourself mighty wrong, Master Ford.

linegroup.speaker: FORD
linegroup.line: Ay, ay; I must bear it.

linegroup.speaker: SIR HUGH EVANS
linegroup.line: If there be any pody in the house, and in the
chambers, and in the coffers, and in the presses,
heaven forgive my sins at the day of judgment!

linegroup.speaker: DOCTOR CAIUS
linegroup.line: By gar, nor I too: there is no bodies.

linegroup.speaker: PAGE
linegroup.line: Fie, fie, Master Ford! are you not ashamed? What
spirit, what devil suggests this imagination? I
would not ha' your distemper in this kind for the
wealth of Windsor Castle.

linegroup.speaker: FORD
linegroup.line: 'Tis my fault, Master Page: I suffer for it.

linegroup.speaker: SIR HUGH EVANS
linegroup.line: You suffer for a pad conscience: your wife is as
honest a 'omans as I will desires among five
thousand, and five hundred too.

linegroup.speaker: DOCTOR CAIUS
linegroup.line: By gar, I see 'tis an honest woman.

linegroup.speaker: FORD
linegroup.line: Well, I promised you a dinner. Come, come, walk in
the Park: I pray you, pardon me; I will hereafter
make known to you why I have done this. Come,
wife; come, Mistress Page. I pray you, pardon me;
pray heartily, pardon me.

linegroup.speaker: PAGE
linegroup.line: Let's go in, gentlemen; but, trust me, we'll mock
him. I do invite you to-morrow morning to my house
to breakfast: after, we'll a-birding together; I
have a fine hawk for the bush. Shall it be so?

linegroup.speaker: FORD
linegroup.line: Any thing.

linegroup.speaker: SIR HUGH EVANS
linegroup.line: If there is one, I shall make two in the company.

linegroup.speaker: DOCTOR CAIUS
linegroup.line: If dere be one or two, I shall make-a the turd.

linegroup.speaker: FORD
linegroup.line: Pray you, go, Master Page.

linegroup.speaker: SIR HUGH EVANS
linegroup.line: I pray you now, remembrance tomorrow on the lousy
knave, mine host.

linegroup.speaker: DOCTOR CAIUS
linegroup.line: Dat is good; by gar, with all my heart!

linegroup.speaker: SIR HUGH EVANS
linegroup.line: A lousy knave, to have his gibes and his mockeries!

section.title: SCENE IV. A room in PAGE'S house.

linegroup.speaker: FENTON
linegroup.line: I see I cannot get thy father's love;
Therefore no more turn me to him, sweet Nan.

linegroup.speaker: ANNE PAGE
linegroup.line: Alas, how then?

linegroup.speaker: FENTON
linegroup.line: Why, thou must be thyself.
He doth object I am too great of birth--,
And that, my state being gall'd with my expense,
I seek to heal it only by his wealth:
Besides these, other bars he lays before me,
My riots past, my wild societies;
And tells me 'tis a thing impossible
I should love thee but as a property.

linegroup.speaker: ANNE PAGE
linegroup.line: May be he tells you true.

linegroup.speaker: FENTON
linegroup.line: No, heaven so speed me in my time to come!
Albeit I will confess thy father's wealth
Was the first motive that I woo'd thee, Anne:
Yet, wooing thee, I found thee of more value
Than stamps in gold or sums in sealed bags;
And 'tis the very riches of thyself
That now I aim at.

linegroup.speaker: ANNE PAGE
linegroup.line: Gentle Master Fenton,
Yet seek my father's love; still seek it, sir:
If opportunity and humblest suit
Cannot attain it, why, then,--hark you hither!

section.para: Enter SHALLOW, SLENDER, and MISTRESS QUICKLY

linegroup.speaker: SHALLOW
linegroup.line: Break their talk, Mistress Quickly: my kinsman shall
speak for himself.

linegroup.speaker: SLENDER
linegroup.line: I'll make a shaft or a bolt on't: 'slid, 'tis but
venturing.

linegroup.speaker: SHALLOW
linegroup.line: Be not dismayed.

linegroup.speaker: SLENDER
linegroup.line: No, she shall not dismay me: I care not for that,
but that I am afeard.

linegroup.speaker: MISTRESS QUICKLY
linegroup.line: Hark ye; Master Slender would speak a word with you.

linegroup.speaker: ANNE PAGE
linegroup.line: I come to him.
This is my father's choice.
O, what a world of vile ill-favor'd faults
Looks handsome in three hundred pounds a-year!

linegroup.speaker: MISTRESS QUICKLY
linegroup.line: And how does good Master Fenton? Pray you, a word with you.

linegroup.speaker: SHALLOW
linegroup.line: She's coming; to her, coz. O boy, thou hadst a father!

linegroup.speaker: SLENDER
linegroup.line: I had a father, Mistress Anne; my uncle can tell you
good jests of him. Pray you, uncle, tell Mistress
Anne the jest, how my father stole two geese out of
a pen, good uncle.

linegroup.speaker: SHALLOW
linegroup.line: Mistress Anne, my cousin loves you.

linegroup.speaker: SLENDER
linegroup.line: Ay, that I do; as well as I love any woman in
Gloucestershire.

linegroup.speaker: SHALLOW
linegroup.line: He will maintain you like a gentlewoman.

linegroup.speaker: SLENDER
linegroup.line: Ay, that I will, come cut and long-tail, under the
degree of a squire.

linegroup.speaker: SHALLOW
linegroup.line: He will make you a hundred and fifty pounds jointure.

linegroup.speaker: ANNE PAGE
linegroup.line: Good Master Shallow, let him woo for himself.

linegroup.speaker: SHALLOW
linegroup.line: Marry, I thank you for it; I thank you for that good
comfort. She calls you, coz: I'll leave you.

linegroup.speaker: ANNE PAGE
linegroup.line: Now, Master Slender,--

linegroup.speaker: SLENDER
linegroup.line: Now, good Mistress Anne,--

linegroup.speaker: ANNE PAGE
linegroup.line: What is your will?

linegroup.speaker: SLENDER
linegroup.line: My will! 'od's heartlings, that's a pretty jest
indeed! I ne'er made my will yet, I thank heaven; I
am not such a sickly creature, I give heaven praise.

linegroup.speaker: ANNE PAGE
linegroup.line: I mean, Master Slender, what would you with me?

linegroup.speaker: SLENDER
linegroup.line: Truly, for mine own part, I would little or nothing
with you. Your father and my uncle hath made
motions: if it be my luck, so; if not, happy man be
his dole! They can tell you how things go better
than I can: you may ask your father; here he comes.

linegroup.speaker: PAGE
linegroup.line: Now, Master Slender: love him, daughter Anne.
Why, how now! what does Master Fenton here?
You wrong me, sir, thus still to haunt my house:
I told you, sir, my daughter is disposed of.

linegroup.speaker: FENTON
linegroup.line: Nay, Master Page, be not impatient.

linegroup.speaker: MISTRESS PAGE
linegroup.line: Good Master Fenton, come not to my child.

linegroup.speaker: PAGE
linegroup.line: She is no match for you.

linegroup.speaker: FENTON
linegroup.line: Sir, will you hear me?

linegroup.speaker: PAGE
linegroup.line: No, good Master Fenton.
Come, Master Shallow; come, son Slender, in.
Knowing my mind, you wrong me, Master Fenton.

linegroup.speaker: MISTRESS QUICKLY
linegroup.line: Speak to Mistress Page.

linegroup.speaker: FENTON
linegroup.line: Good Mistress Page, for that I love your daughter
In such a righteous fashion as I do,
Perforce, against all cheques, rebukes and manners,
I must advance the colours of my love
And not retire: let me have your good will.

linegroup.speaker: ANNE PAGE
linegroup.line: Good mother, do not marry me to yond fool.

linegroup.speaker: MISTRESS PAGE
linegroup.line: I mean it not; I seek you a better husband.

linegroup.speaker: MISTRESS QUICKLY
linegroup.line: That's my master, master doctor.

linegroup.speaker: ANNE PAGE
linegroup.line: Alas, I had rather be set quick i' the earth
And bowl'd to death with turnips!

linegroup.speaker: MISTRESS PAGE
linegroup.line: Come, trouble not yourself. Good Master Fenton,
I will not be your friend nor enemy:
My daughter will I question how she loves you,
And as I find her, so am I affected.
Till then farewell, sir: she must needs go in;
Her father will be angry.

linegroup.speaker: FENTON
linegroup.line: Farewell, gentle mistress: farewell, Nan.

section.para: Exeunt MISTRESS PAGE and ANNE PAGE

linegroup.speaker: MISTRESS QUICKLY
linegroup.line: This is my doing, now: 'Nay,' said I, 'will you cast
away your child on a fool, and a physician? Look on
Master Fenton:' this is my doing.

linegroup.speaker: FENTON
linegroup.line: I thank thee; and I pray thee, once to-night
Give my sweet Nan this ring: there's for thy pains.

linegroup.speaker: MISTRESS QUICKLY
linegroup.line: Now heaven send thee good fortune!
A kind heart he hath: a woman would run through
fire and water for such a kind heart. But yet I
would my master had Mistress Anne; or I would
Master Slender had her; or, in sooth, I would Master
Fenton had her; I will do what I can for them all
three; for so I have promised, and I'll be as good
as my word; but speciously for Master Fenton. Well,
I must of another errand to Sir John Falstaff from
my two mistresses: what a beast am I to slack it!

section.title: SCENE V. A room in the Garter Inn.

linegroup.speaker: FALSTAFF
linegroup.line: Bardolph, I say,--

linegroup.speaker: BARDOLPH
linegroup.line: Here, sir.

linegroup.speaker: FALSTAFF
linegroup.line: Go fetch me a quart of sack; put a toast in't.
Have I lived to be carried in a basket, like a
barrow of butcher's offal, and to be thrown in the
Thames? Well, if I be served such another trick,
I'll have my brains ta'en out and buttered, and give
them to a dog for a new-year's gift. The rogues
slighted me into the river with as little remorse as
they would have drowned a blind bitch's puppies,
fifteen i' the litter: and you may know by my size
that I have a kind of alacrity in sinking; if the
bottom were as deep as hell, I should down. I had
been drowned, but that the shore was shelvy and
shallow,--a death that I abhor; for the water swells
a man; and what a thing should I have been when I
had been swelled! I should have been a mountain of mummy.

linegroup.speaker: BARDOLPH
linegroup.line: Here's Mistress Quickly, sir, to speak with you.

linegroup.speaker: FALSTAFF
linegroup.line: Let me pour in some sack to the Thames water; for my
belly's as cold as if I had swallowed snowballs for
pills to cool the reins. Call her in.

linegroup.speaker: BARDOLPH
linegroup.line: Come in, woman!

linegroup.speaker: MISTRESS QUICKLY
linegroup.line: By your leave; I cry you mercy: give your worship
good morrow.

linegroup.speaker: FALSTAFF
linegroup.line: Take away these chalices. Go brew me a pottle of
sack finely.

linegroup.speaker: BARDOLPH
linegroup.line: With eggs, sir?

linegroup.speaker: FALSTAFF
linegroup.line: Simple of itself; I'll no pullet-sperm in my brewage.
How now!

linegroup.speaker: MISTRESS QUICKLY
linegroup.line: Marry, sir, I come to your worship from Mistress Ford.

linegroup.speaker: FALSTAFF
linegroup.line: Mistress Ford! I have had ford enough; I was thrown
into the ford; I have my belly full of ford.

linegroup.speaker: MISTRESS QUICKLY
linegroup.line: Alas the day! good heart, that was not her fault:
she does so take on with her men; they mistook their erection.

linegroup.speaker: FALSTAFF
linegroup.line: So did I mine, to build upon a foolish woman's promise.

linegroup.speaker: MISTRESS QUICKLY
linegroup.line: Well, she laments, sir, for it, that it would yearn
your heart to see it. Her husband goes this morning
a-birding; she desires you once more to come to her
between eight and nine: I must carry her word
quickly: she'll make you amends, I warrant you.

linegroup.speaker: FALSTAFF
linegroup.line: Well, I will visit her: tell her so; and bid her
think what a man is: let her consider his frailty,
and then judge of my merit.

linegroup.speaker: MISTRESS QUICKLY
linegroup.line: I will tell her.

linegroup.speaker: FALSTAFF
linegroup.line: Do so. Between nine and ten, sayest thou?

linegroup.speaker: MISTRESS QUICKLY
linegroup.line: Eight and nine, sir.

linegroup.speaker: FALSTAFF
linegroup.line: Well, be gone: I will not miss her.

linegroup.speaker: MISTRESS QUICKLY
linegroup.line: Peace be with you, sir.

linegroup.speaker: FALSTAFF
linegroup.line: I marvel I hear not of Master Brook; he sent me word
to stay within: I like his money well. O, here he comes.

linegroup.speaker: FORD
linegroup.line: Bless you, sir!

linegroup.speaker: FALSTAFF
linegroup.line: Now, master Brook, you come to know what hath passed
between me and Ford's wife?

linegroup.speaker: FORD
linegroup.line: That, indeed, Sir John, is my business.

linegroup.speaker: FALSTAFF
linegroup.line: Master Brook, I will not lie to you: I was at her
house the hour she appointed me.

linegroup.speaker: FORD
linegroup.line: And sped you, sir?

linegroup.speaker: FALSTAFF
linegroup.line: Very ill-favoredly, Master Brook.

linegroup.speaker: FORD
linegroup.line: How so, sir? Did she change her determination?

linegroup.speaker: FALSTAFF
linegroup.line: No, Master Brook; but the peaking Cornuto her
husband, Master Brook, dwelling in a continual
'larum of jealousy, comes me in the instant of our
encounter, after we had embraced, kissed, protested,
and, as it were, spoke the prologue of our comedy;
and at his heels a rabble of his companions, thither
provoked and instigated by his distemper, and,
forsooth, to search his house for his wife's love.

linegroup.speaker: FORD
linegroup.line: What, while you were there?

linegroup.speaker: FALSTAFF
linegroup.line: While I was there.

linegroup.speaker: FORD
linegroup.line: And did he search for you, and could not find you?

linegroup.speaker: FALSTAFF
linegroup.line: You shall hear. As good luck would have it, comes
in one Mistress Page; gives intelligence of Ford's
approach; and, in her invention and Ford's wife's
distraction, they conveyed me into a buck-basket.

linegroup.speaker: FORD
linegroup.line: A buck-basket!

linegroup.speaker: FALSTAFF
linegroup.line: By the Lord, a buck-basket! rammed me in with foul
shirts and smocks, socks, foul stockings, greasy
napkins; that, Master Brook, there was the rankest
compound of villanous smell that ever offended nostril.

linegroup.speaker: FORD
linegroup.line: And how long lay you there?

linegroup.speaker: FALSTAFF
linegroup.line: Nay, you shall hear, Master Brook, what I have
suffered to bring this woman to evil for your good.
Being thus crammed in the basket, a couple of Ford's
knaves, his hinds, were called forth by their
mistress to carry me in the name of foul clothes to
Datchet-lane: they took me on their shoulders; met
the jealous knave their master in the door, who
asked them once or twice what they had in their
basket: I quaked for fear, lest the lunatic knave
would have searched it; but fate, ordaining he
should be a cuckold, held his hand. Well: on went he
for a search, and away went I for foul clothes. But
mark the sequel, Master Brook: I suffered the pangs
of three several deaths; first, an intolerable
fright, to be detected with a jealous rotten
bell-wether; next, to be compassed, like a good
bilbo, in the circumference of a peck, hilt to
point, heel to head; and then, to be stopped in,
like a strong distillation, with stinking clothes
that fretted in their own grease: think of that,--a
man of my kidney,--think of that,--that am as subject
to heat as butter; a man of continual dissolution
and thaw: it was a miracle to scape suffocation.
And in the height of this bath, when I was more than
half stewed in grease, like a Dutch dish, to be
thrown into the Thames, and cooled, glowing hot,
in that surge, like a horse-shoe; think of
that,--hissing hot,--think of that, Master Brook.

linegroup.speaker: FORD
linegroup.line: In good sadness, I am sorry that for my sake you
have sufferd all this. My suit then is desperate;
you'll undertake her no more?

linegroup.speaker: FALSTAFF
linegroup.line: Master Brook, I will be thrown into Etna, as I have
been into Thames, ere I will leave her thus. Her
husband is this morning gone a-birding: I have
received from her another embassy of meeting; 'twixt
eight and nine is the hour, Master Brook.

linegroup.speaker: FORD
linegroup.line: 'Tis past eight already, sir.

linegroup.speaker: FALSTAFF
linegroup.line: Is it? I will then address me to my appointment.
Come to me at your convenient leisure, and you shall
know how I speed; and the conclusion shall be
crowned with your enjoying her. Adieu. You shall
have her, Master Brook; Master Brook, you shall
cuckold Ford.

linegroup.speaker: FORD
linegroup.line: Hum! ha! is this a vision? is this a dream? do I
sleep? Master Ford awake! awake, Master Ford!
there's a hole made in your best coat, Master Ford.
This 'tis to be married! this 'tis to have linen
and buck-baskets! Well, I will proclaim myself
what I am: I will now take the lecher; he is at my
house; he cannot 'scape me; 'tis impossible he
should; he cannot creep into a halfpenny purse,
nor into a pepper-box: but, lest the devil that
guides him should aid him, I will search
impossible places. Though what I am I cannot avoid,
yet to be what I would not shall not make me tame:
if I have horns to make one mad, let the proverb go
with me: I'll be horn-mad.

section.title: SCENE I. A street.
section.para: Enter MISTRESS PAGE, MISTRESS QUICKLY, and WILLIAM PAGE

linegroup.speaker: MISTRESS PAGE
linegroup.line: Is he at Master Ford's already, think'st thou?

linegroup.speaker: MISTRESS QUICKLY
linegroup.line: Sure he is by this, or will be presently: but,
truly, he is very courageous mad about his throwing
into the water. Mistress Ford desires you to come suddenly.

linegroup.speaker: MISTRESS PAGE
linegroup.line: I'll be with her by and by; I'll but bring my young
man here to school. Look, where his master comes;
'tis a playing-day, I see.
How now, Sir Hugh! no school to-day?

linegroup.speaker: SIR HUGH EVANS
linegroup.line: No; Master Slender is let the boys leave to play.

linegroup.speaker: MISTRESS QUICKLY
linegroup.line: Blessing of his heart!

linegroup.speaker: MISTRESS PAGE
linegroup.line: Sir Hugh, my husband says my son profits nothing in
the world at his book. I pray you, ask him some
questions in his accidence.

linegroup.speaker: SIR HUGH EVANS
linegroup.line: Come hither, William; hold up your head; come.

linegroup.speaker: MISTRESS PAGE
linegroup.line: Come on, sirrah; hold up your head; answer your
master, be not afraid.

linegroup.speaker: SIR HUGH EVANS
linegroup.line: William, how many numbers is in nouns?

linegroup.speaker: WILLIAM PAGE
linegroup.line: Two.

linegroup.speaker: MISTRESS QUICKLY
linegroup.line: Truly, I thought there had been one number more,
because they say, ''Od's nouns.'

linegroup.speaker: SIR HUGH EVANS
linegroup.line: Peace your tattlings! What is 'fair,' William?

linegroup.speaker: WILLIAM PAGE
linegroup.line: Pulcher.

linegroup.speaker: MISTRESS QUICKLY
linegroup.line: Polecats! there are fairer things than polecats, sure.

linegroup.speaker: SIR HUGH EVANS
linegroup.line: You are a very simplicity 'oman: I pray you peace.
What is 'lapis,' William?

linegroup.speaker: WILLIAM PAGE
linegroup.line: A stone.

linegroup.speaker: SIR HUGH EVANS
linegroup.line: And what is 'a stone,' William?

linegroup.speaker: WILLIAM PAGE
linegroup.line: A pebble.

linegroup.speaker: SIR HUGH EVANS
linegroup.line: No, it is 'lapis:' I pray you, remember in your prain.

linegroup.speaker: WILLIAM PAGE
linegroup.line: Lapis.

linegroup.speaker: SIR HUGH EVANS
linegroup.line: That is a good William. What is he, William, that
does lend articles?

linegroup.speaker: WILLIAM PAGE
linegroup.line: Articles are borrowed of the pronoun, and be thus
declined, Singulariter, nominativo, hic, haec, hoc.

linegroup.speaker: SIR HUGH EVANS
linegroup.line: Nominativo, hig, hag, hog; pray you, mark:
genitivo, hujus. Well, what is your accusative case?

linegroup.speaker: WILLIAM PAGE
linegroup.line: Accusativo, hinc.

linegroup.speaker: SIR HUGH EVANS
linegroup.line: I pray you, have your remembrance, child,
accusative, hung, hang, hog.

linegroup.speaker: MISTRESS QUICKLY
linegroup.line: 'Hang-hog' is Latin for bacon, I warrant you.

linegroup.speaker: SIR HUGH EVANS
linegroup.line: Leave your prabbles, 'oman. What is the focative
case, William?

linegroup.speaker: WILLIAM PAGE
linegroup.line: O,--vocativo, O.

linegroup.speaker: SIR HUGH EVANS
linegroup.line: Remember, William; focative is caret.

linegroup.speaker: MISTRESS QUICKLY
linegroup.line: And that's a good root.

linegroup.speaker: SIR HUGH EVANS
linegroup.line: 'Oman, forbear.

linegroup.speaker: MISTRESS PAGE
linegroup.line: Peace!

linegroup.speaker: SIR HUGH EVANS
linegroup.line: What is your genitive case plural, William?

linegroup.speaker: WILLIAM PAGE
linegroup.line: Genitive case!

linegroup.speaker: SIR HUGH EVANS
linegroup.line: Ay.

linegroup.speaker: WILLIAM PAGE
linegroup.line: Genitive,--horum, harum, horum.

linegroup.speaker: MISTRESS QUICKLY
linegroup.line: Vengeance of Jenny's case! fie on her! never name
her, child, if she be a whore.

linegroup.speaker: SIR HUGH EVANS
linegroup.line: For shame, 'oman.

linegroup.speaker: MISTRESS QUICKLY
linegroup.line: You do ill to teach the child such words: he
teaches him to hick and to hack, which they'll do
fast enough of themselves, and to call 'horum:' fie upon you!

linegroup.speaker: SIR HUGH EVANS
linegroup.line: 'Oman, art thou lunatics? hast thou no
understandings for thy cases and the numbers of the
genders? Thou art as foolish Christian creatures as
I would desires.

linegroup.speaker: MISTRESS PAGE
linegroup.line: Prithee, hold thy peace.

linegroup.speaker: SIR HUGH EVANS
linegroup.line: Show me now, William, some declensions of your pronouns.

linegroup.speaker: WILLIAM PAGE
linegroup.line: Forsooth, I have forgot.

linegroup.speaker: SIR HUGH EVANS
linegroup.line: It is qui, quae, quod: if you forget your 'quies,'
your 'quaes,' and your 'quods,' you must be
preeches. Go your ways, and play; go.

linegroup.speaker: MISTRESS PAGE
linegroup.line: He is a better scholar than I thought he was.

linegroup.speaker: SIR HUGH EVANS
linegroup.line: He is a good sprag memory. Farewell, Mistress Page.

linegroup.speaker: MISTRESS PAGE
linegroup.line: Adieu, good Sir Hugh.
Get you home, boy. Come, we stay too long.

section.title: SCENE II. A room in FORD'S house.

linegroup.speaker: FALSTAFF
linegroup.line: Mistress Ford, your sorrow hath eaten up my
sufferance. I see you are obsequious in your love,
and I profess requital to a hair's breadth; not
only, Mistress Ford, in the simple
office of love, but in all the accoutrement,
complement and ceremony of it. But are you
sure of your husband now?

linegroup.speaker: MISTRESS FORD
linegroup.line: He's a-birding, sweet Sir John.

linegroup.speaker: MISTRESS PAGE
linegroup.line: Within What, ho, gossip Ford! what, ho!

linegroup.speaker: MISTRESS FORD
linegroup.line: Step into the chamber, Sir John.

linegroup.speaker: MISTRESS PAGE
linegroup.line: How now, sweetheart! who's at home besides yourself?

linegroup.speaker: MISTRESS FORD
linegroup.line: Why, none but mine own people.

linegroup.speaker: MISTRESS PAGE
linegroup.line: Indeed!

linegroup.speaker: MISTRESS FORD
linegroup.line: No, certainly.
Speak louder.

linegroup.speaker: MISTRESS PAGE
linegroup.line: Truly, I am so glad you have nobody here.

linegroup.speaker: MISTRESS FORD
linegroup.line: Why?

linegroup.speaker: MISTRESS PAGE
linegroup.line: Why, woman, your husband is in his old lunes again:
he so takes on yonder with my husband; so rails
against all married mankind; so curses all Eve's
daughters, of what complexion soever; and so buffets
himself on the forehead, crying, 'Peer out, peer
out!' that any madness I ever yet beheld seemed but
tameness, civility and patience, to this his
distemper he is in now: I am glad the fat knight is not here.

linegroup.speaker: MISTRESS FORD
linegroup.line: Why, does he talk of him?

linegroup.speaker: MISTRESS PAGE
linegroup.line: Of none but him; and swears he was carried out, the
last time he searched for him, in a basket; protests
to my husband he is now here, and hath drawn him and
the rest of their company from their sport, to make
another experiment of his suspicion: but I am glad
the knight is not here; now he shall see his own foolery.

linegroup.speaker: MISTRESS FORD
linegroup.line: How near is he, Mistress Page?

linegroup.speaker: MISTRESS PAGE
linegroup.line: Hard by; at street end; he will be here anon.

linegroup.speaker: MISTRESS FORD
linegroup.line: I am undone! The knight is here.

linegroup.speaker: MISTRESS PAGE
linegroup.line: Why then you are utterly shamed, and he's but a dead
man. What a woman are you!--Away with him, away
with him! better shame than murder.

linegroup.speaker: FORD
linegroup.line: Which way should be go? how should I bestow him?
Shall I put him into the basket again?

linegroup.speaker: FALSTAFF
linegroup.line: No, I'll come no more i' the basket. May I not go
out ere he come?

linegroup.speaker: MISTRESS PAGE
linegroup.line: Alas, three of Master Ford's brothers watch the door
with pistols, that none shall issue out; otherwise
you might slip away ere he came. But what make you here?

linegroup.speaker: FALSTAFF
linegroup.line: What shall I do? I'll creep up into the chimney.

linegroup.speaker: MISTRESS FORD
linegroup.line: There they always use to discharge their
birding-pieces. Creep into the kiln-hole.

linegroup.speaker: FALSTAFF
linegroup.line: Where is it?

linegroup.speaker: MISTRESS FORD
linegroup.line: He will seek there, on my word. Neither press,
coffer, chest, trunk, well, vault, but he hath an
abstract for the remembrance of such places, and
goes to them by his note: there is no hiding you in the house.

linegroup.speaker: FALSTAFF
linegroup.line: I'll go out then.

linegroup.speaker: MISTRESS PAGE
linegroup.line: If you go out in your own semblance, you die, Sir
John. Unless you go out disguised--

linegroup.speaker: MISTRESS FORD
linegroup.line: How might we disguise him?

linegroup.speaker: MISTRESS PAGE
linegroup.line: Alas the day, I know not! There is no woman's gown
big enough for him otherwise he might put on a hat,
a muffler and a kerchief, and so escape.

linegroup.speaker: FALSTAFF
linegroup.line: Good hearts, devise something: any extremity rather
than a mischief.

linegroup.speaker: MISTRESS FORD
linegroup.line: My maid's aunt, the fat woman of Brentford, has a
gown above.

linegroup.speaker: MISTRESS PAGE
linegroup.line: On my word, it will serve him; she's as big as he
is: and there's her thrummed hat and her muffler
too. Run up, Sir John.

linegroup.speaker: MISTRESS FORD
linegroup.line: Go, go, sweet Sir John: Mistress Page and I will
look some linen for your head.

linegroup.speaker: MISTRESS PAGE
linegroup.line: Quick, quick! we'll come dress you straight: put
on the gown the while.

linegroup.speaker: MISTRESS FORD
linegroup.line: I would my husband would meet him in this shape: he
cannot abide the old woman of Brentford; he swears
she's a witch; forbade her my house and hath
threatened to beat her.

linegroup.speaker: MISTRESS PAGE
linegroup.line: Heaven guide him to thy husband's cudgel, and the
devil guide his cudgel afterwards!

linegroup.speaker: MISTRESS FORD
linegroup.line: But is my husband coming?

linegroup.speaker: MISTRESS PAGE
linegroup.line: Ah, in good sadness, is he; and talks of the basket
too, howsoever he hath had intelligence.

linegroup.speaker: MISTRESS FORD
linegroup.line: We'll try that; for I'll appoint my men to carry the
basket again, to meet him at the door with it, as
they did last time.

linegroup.speaker: MISTRESS PAGE
linegroup.line: Nay, but he'll be here presently: let's go dress him
like the witch of Brentford.

linegroup.speaker: MISTRESS FORD
linegroup.line: I'll first direct my men what they shall do with the
basket. Go up; I'll bring linen for him straight.

linegroup.speaker: MISTRESS PAGE
linegroup.line: Hang him, dishonest varlet! we cannot misuse him enough.
We'll leave a proof, by that which we will do,
Wives may be merry, and yet honest too:
We do not act that often jest and laugh;
'Tis old, but true, Still swine eat all the draff.

section.para: Re-enter MISTRESS FORD with two Servants

linegroup.speaker: MISTRESS FORD
linegroup.line: Go, sirs, take the basket again on your shoulders:
your master is hard at door; if he bid you set it
down, obey him: quickly, dispatch.

linegroup.speaker: First Servant
linegroup.line: Come, come, take it up.

linegroup.speaker: Second Servant
linegroup.line: Pray heaven it be not full of knight again.

linegroup.speaker: First Servant
linegroup.line: I hope not; I had as lief bear so much lead.

section.para: Enter FORD, PAGE, SHALLOW, DOCTOR CAIUS, and SIR HUGH EVANS

linegroup.speaker: FORD
linegroup.line: Ay, but if it prove true, Master Page, have you any
way then to unfool me again? Set down the basket,
villain! Somebody call my wife. Youth in a basket!
O you panderly rascals! there's a knot, a ging, a
pack, a conspiracy against me: now shall the devil
be shamed. What, wife, I say! Come, come forth!
Behold what honest clothes you send forth to bleaching!

linegroup.speaker: PAGE
linegroup.line: Why, this passes, Master Ford; you are not to go
loose any longer; you must be pinioned.

linegroup.speaker: SIR HUGH EVANS
linegroup.line: Why, this is lunatics! this is mad as a mad dog!

linegroup.speaker: SHALLOW
linegroup.line: Indeed, Master Ford, this is not well, indeed.

linegroup.speaker: FORD
linegroup.line: So say I too, sir.
Come hither, Mistress Ford; Mistress Ford the honest
woman, the modest wife, the virtuous creature, that
hath the jealous fool to her husband! I suspect
without cause, mistress, do I?

linegroup.speaker: MISTRESS FORD
linegroup.line: Heaven be my witness you do, if you suspect me in
any dishonesty.

linegroup.speaker: FORD
linegroup.line: Well said, brazen-face! hold it out. Come forth, sirrah!

section.para: Pulling clothes out of the basket

linegroup.speaker: PAGE
linegroup.line: This passes!

linegroup.speaker: MISTRESS FORD
linegroup.line: Are you not ashamed? let the clothes alone.

linegroup.speaker: FORD
linegroup.line: I shall find you anon.

linegroup.speaker: SIR HUGH EVANS
linegroup.line: 'Tis unreasonable! Will you take up your wife's
clothes? Come away.

linegroup.speaker: FORD
linegroup.line: Empty the basket, I say!

linegroup.speaker: MISTRESS FORD
linegroup.line: Why, man, why?

linegroup.speaker: FORD
linegroup.line: Master Page, as I am a man, there was one conveyed
out of my house yesterday in this basket: why may
not he be there again? In my house I am sure he is:
my intelligence is true; my jealousy is reasonable.
Pluck me out all the linen.

linegroup.speaker: MISTRESS FORD
linegroup.line: If you find a man there, he shall die a flea's death.

linegroup.speaker: PAGE
linegroup.line: Here's no man.

linegroup.speaker: SHALLOW
linegroup.line: By my fidelity, this is not well, Master Ford; this
wrongs you.

linegroup.speaker: SIR HUGH EVANS
linegroup.line: Master Ford, you must pray, and not follow the
imaginations of your own heart: this is jealousies.

linegroup.speaker: FORD
linegroup.line: Well, he's not here I seek for.

linegroup.speaker: PAGE
linegroup.line: No, nor nowhere else but in your brain.

linegroup.speaker: FORD
linegroup.line: Help to search my house this one time. If I find
not what I seek, show no colour for my extremity; let
me for ever be your table-sport; let them say of
me, 'As jealous as Ford, Chat searched a hollow
walnut for his wife's leman.' Satisfy me once more;
once more search with me.

linegroup.speaker: MISTRESS FORD
linegroup.line: What, ho, Mistress Page! come you and the old woman
down; my husband will come into the chamber.

linegroup.speaker: FORD
linegroup.line: Old woman! what old woman's that?

linegroup.speaker: MISTRESS FORD
linegroup.line: Nay, it is my maid's aunt of Brentford.

linegroup.speaker: FORD
linegroup.line: A witch, a quean, an old cozening quean! Have I not
forbid her my house? She comes of errands, does
she? We are simple men; we do not know what's
brought to pass under the profession of
fortune-telling. She works by charms, by spells,
by the figure, and such daubery as this is, beyond
our element we know nothing. Come down, you witch,
you hag, you; come down, I say!

linegroup.speaker: MISTRESS FORD
linegroup.line: Nay, good, sweet husband! Good gentlemen, let him
not strike the old woman.

section.para: Re-enter FALSTAFF in woman's clothes, and MISTRESS PAGE

linegroup.speaker: MISTRESS PAGE
linegroup.line: Come, Mother Prat; come, give me your hand.

linegroup.speaker: FORD
linegroup.line: I'll prat her.
Out of my door, you witch, you hag, you baggage, you
polecat, you runyon! out, out! I'll conjure you,
I'll fortune-tell you.

linegroup.speaker: MISTRESS PAGE
linegroup.line: Are you not ashamed? I think you have killed the
poor woman.

linegroup.speaker: MISTRESS FORD
linegroup.line: Nay, he will do it. 'Tis a goodly credit for you.

linegroup.speaker: FORD
linegroup.line: Hang her, witch!

linegroup.speaker: SIR HUGH EVANS
linegroup.line: By the yea and no, I think the 'oman is a witch
indeed: I like not when a 'oman has a great peard;
I spy a great peard under his muffler.

linegroup.speaker: FORD
linegroup.line: Will you follow, gentlemen? I beseech you, follow;
see but the issue of my jealousy: if I cry out thus
upon no trail, never trust me when I open again.

linegroup.speaker: PAGE
linegroup.line: Let's obey his humour a little further: come,
gentlemen.

section.para: Exeunt FORD, PAGE, SHALLOW, DOCTOR CAIUS, and SIR HUGH EVANS

linegroup.speaker: MISTRESS PAGE
linegroup.line: Trust me, he beat him most pitifully.

linegroup.speaker: MISTRESS FORD
linegroup.line: Nay, by the mass, that he did not; he beat him most
unpitifully, methought.

linegroup.speaker: MISTRESS PAGE
linegroup.line: I'll have the cudgel hallowed and hung o'er the
altar; it hath done meritorious service.

linegroup.speaker: MISTRESS FORD
linegroup.line: What think you? may we, with the warrant of
womanhood and the witness of a good conscience,
pursue him with any further revenge?

linegroup.speaker: MISTRESS PAGE
linegroup.line: The spirit of wantonness is, sure, scared out of
him: if the devil have him not in fee-simple, with
fine and recovery, he will never, I think, in the
way of waste, attempt us again.

linegroup.speaker: MISTRESS FORD
linegroup.line: Shall we tell our husbands how we have served him?

linegroup.speaker: MISTRESS PAGE
linegroup.line: Yes, by all means; if it be but to scrape the
figures out of your husband's brains. If they can
find in their hearts the poor unvirtuous fat knight
shall be any further afflicted, we two will still be
the ministers.

linegroup.speaker: MISTRESS FORD
linegroup.line: I'll warrant they'll have him publicly shamed: and
methinks there would be no period to the jest,
should he not be publicly shamed.

linegroup.speaker: MISTRESS PAGE
linegroup.line: Come, to the forge with it then; shape it: I would
not have things cool.

section.title: SCENE III. A room in the Garter Inn.

linegroup.speaker: BARDOLPH
linegroup.line: Sir, the Germans desire to have three of your
horses: the duke himself will be to-morrow at
court, and they are going to meet him.

linegroup.speaker: Host
linegroup.line: What duke should that be comes so secretly? I hear
not of him in the court. Let me speak with the
gentlemen: they speak English?

linegroup.speaker: BARDOLPH
linegroup.line: Ay, sir; I'll call them to you.

linegroup.speaker: Host
linegroup.line: They shall have my horses; but I'll make them pay;
I'll sauce them: they have had my house a week at
command; I have turned away my other guests: they
must come off; I'll sauce them. Come.

section.title: SCENE IV. A room in FORD'S house.
section.para: Enter PAGE, FORD, MISTRESS PAGE, MISTRESS FORD, and SIR HUGH EVANS

linegroup.speaker: SIR HUGH EVANS
linegroup.line: 'Tis one of the best discretions of a 'oman as ever
I did look upon.

linegroup.speaker: PAGE
linegroup.line: And did he send you both these letters at an instant?

linegroup.speaker: MISTRESS PAGE
linegroup.line: Within a quarter of an hour.

linegroup.speaker: FORD
linegroup.line: Pardon me, wife. Henceforth do what thou wilt;
I rather will suspect the sun with cold
Than thee with wantonness: now doth thy honour stand
In him that was of late an heretic,
As firm as faith.

linegroup.speaker: PAGE
linegroup.line: 'Tis well, 'tis well; no more:
Be not as extreme in submission
As in offence.
But let our plot go forward: let our wives
Yet once again, to make us public sport,
Appoint a meeting with this old fat fellow,
Where we may take him and disgrace him for it.

linegroup.speaker: FORD
linegroup.line: There is no better way than that they spoke of.

linegroup.speaker: PAGE
linegroup.line: How? to send him word they'll meet him in the park
at midnight? Fie, fie! he'll never come.

linegroup.speaker: SIR HUGH EVANS
linegroup.line: You say he has been thrown in the rivers and has
been grievously peaten as an old 'oman: methinks
there should be terrors in him that he should not
come; methinks his flesh is punished, he shall have
no desires.

linegroup.speaker: PAGE
linegroup.line: So think I too.

linegroup.speaker: MISTRESS FORD
linegroup.line: Devise but how you'll use him when he comes,
And let us two devise to bring him thither.

linegroup.speaker: MISTRESS PAGE
linegroup.line: There is an old tale goes that Herne the hunter,
Sometime a keeper here in Windsor forest,
Doth all the winter-time, at still midnight,
Walk round about an oak, with great ragg'd horns;
And there he blasts the tree and takes the cattle
And makes milch-kine yield blood and shakes a chain
In a most hideous and dreadful manner:
You have heard of such a spirit, and well you know
The superstitious idle-headed eld
Received and did deliver to our age
This tale of Herne the hunter for a truth.

linegroup.speaker: PAGE
linegroup.line: Why, yet there want not many that do fear
In deep of night to walk by this Herne's oak:
But what of this?

linegroup.speaker: MISTRESS FORD
linegroup.line: Marry, this is our device;
That Falstaff at that oak shall meet with us.

linegroup.speaker: PAGE
linegroup.line: Well, let it not be doubted but he'll come:
And in this shape when you have brought him thither,
What shall be done with him? what is your plot?

linegroup.speaker: MISTRESS PAGE
linegroup.line: That likewise have we thought upon, and thus:
Nan Page my daughter and my little son
And three or four more of their growth we'll dress
Like urchins, ouphes and fairies, green and white,
With rounds of waxen tapers on their heads,
And rattles in their hands: upon a sudden,
As Falstaff, she and I, are newly met,
Let them from forth a sawpit rush at once
With some diffused song: upon their sight,
We two in great amazedness will fly:
Then let them all encircle him about
And, fairy-like, to-pinch the unclean knight,
And ask him why, that hour of fairy revel,
In their so sacred paths he dares to tread
In shape profane.

linegroup.speaker: MISTRESS FORD
linegroup.line: And till he tell the truth,
Let the supposed fairies pinch him sound
And burn him with their tapers.

linegroup.speaker: MISTRESS PAGE
linegroup.line: The truth being known,
We'll all present ourselves, dis-horn the spirit,
And mock him home to Windsor.

linegroup.speaker: FORD
linegroup.line: The children must
Be practised well to this, or they'll ne'er do't.

linegroup.speaker: SIR HUGH EVANS
linegroup.line: I will teach the children their behaviors; and I
will be like a jack-an-apes also, to burn the
knight with my taber.

linegroup.speaker: FORD
linegroup.line: That will be excellent. I'll go and buy them vizards.

linegroup.speaker: MISTRESS PAGE
linegroup.line: My Nan shall be the queen of all the fairies,
Finely attired in a robe of white.

linegroup.speaker: PAGE
linegroup.line: That silk will I go buy.
And in that time
Shall Master Slender steal my Nan away
And marry her at Eton. Go send to Falstaff straight.

linegroup.speaker: FORD
linegroup.line: Nay I'll to him again in name of Brook
He'll tell me all his purpose: sure, he'll come.

linegroup.speaker: MISTRESS PAGE
linegroup.line: Fear not you that. Go get us properties
And tricking for our fairies.

linegroup.speaker: SIR HUGH EVANS
linegroup.line: Let us about it: it is admirable pleasures and fery
honest knaveries.

section.para: Exeunt PAGE, FORD, and SIR HUGH EVANS

linegroup.speaker: MISTRESS PAGE
linegroup.line: Go, Mistress Ford,
Send quickly to Sir John, to know his mind.
I'll to the doctor: he hath my good will,
And none but he, to marry with Nan Page.
That Slender, though well landed, is an idiot;
And he my husband best of all affects.
The doctor is well money'd, and his friends
Potent at court: he, none but he, shall have her,
Though twenty thousand worthier come to crave her.

section.title: SCENE V. A room in the Garter Inn.

linegroup.speaker: Host
linegroup.line: What wouldst thou have, boor? what: thick-skin?
speak, breathe, discuss; brief, short, quick, snap.

linegroup.speaker: SIMPLE
linegroup.line: Marry, sir, I come to speak with Sir John Falstaff
from Master Slender.

linegroup.speaker: Host
linegroup.line: There's his chamber, his house, his castle, his
standing-bed and truckle-bed; 'tis painted about
with the story of the Prodigal, fresh and new. Go
knock and call; hell speak like an Anthropophaginian
unto thee: knock, I say.

linegroup.speaker: SIMPLE
linegroup.line: There's an old woman, a fat woman, gone up into his
chamber: I'll be so bold as stay, sir, till she come
down; I come to speak with her, indeed.

linegroup.speaker: Host
linegroup.line: Ha! a fat woman! the knight may be robbed: I'll
call. Bully knight! bully Sir John! speak from
thy lungs military: art thou there? it is thine
host, thine Ephesian, calls.

linegroup.speaker: FALSTAFF
linegroup.line: Above How now, mine host!

linegroup.speaker: Host
linegroup.line: Here's a Bohemian-Tartar tarries the coming down of
thy fat woman. Let her descend, bully, let her
descend; my chambers are honourable: fie! privacy?
fie!

linegroup.speaker: FALSTAFF
linegroup.line: There was, mine host, an old fat woman even now with
me; but she's gone.

linegroup.speaker: SIMPLE
linegroup.line: Pray you, sir, was't not the wise woman of
Brentford?

linegroup.speaker: FALSTAFF
linegroup.line: Ay, marry, was it, mussel-shell: what would you with her?

linegroup.speaker: SIMPLE
linegroup.line: My master, sir, Master Slender, sent to her, seeing
her go through the streets, to know, sir, whether
one Nym, sir, that beguiled him of a chain, had the
chain or no.

linegroup.speaker: FALSTAFF
linegroup.line: I spake with the old woman about it.

linegroup.speaker: SIMPLE
linegroup.line: And what says she, I pray, sir?

linegroup.speaker: FALSTAFF
linegroup.line: Marry, she says that the very same man that
beguiled Master Slender of his chain cozened him of
it.

linegroup.speaker: SIMPLE
linegroup.line: I would I could have spoken with the woman herself;
I had other things to have spoken with her too from
him.

linegroup.speaker: FALSTAFF
linegroup.line: What are they? let us know.

linegroup.speaker: Host
linegroup.line: Ay, come; quick.

linegroup.speaker: SIMPLE
linegroup.line: I may not conceal them, sir.

linegroup.speaker: Host
linegroup.line: Conceal them, or thou diest.

linegroup.speaker: SIMPLE
linegroup.line: Why, sir, they were nothing but about Mistress Anne
Page; to know if it were my master's fortune to
have her or no.

linegroup.speaker: FALSTAFF
linegroup.line: 'Tis, 'tis his fortune.

linegroup.speaker: SIMPLE
linegroup.line: What, sir?

linegroup.speaker: FALSTAFF
linegroup.line: To have her, or no. Go; say the woman told me so.

linegroup.speaker: SIMPLE
linegroup.line: May I be bold to say so, sir?

linegroup.speaker: FALSTAFF
linegroup.line: Ay, sir; like who more bold.

linegroup.speaker: SIMPLE
linegroup.line: I thank your worship: I shall make my master glad
with these tidings.

linegroup.speaker: Host
linegroup.line: Thou art clerkly, thou art clerkly, Sir John. Was
there a wise woman with thee?

linegroup.speaker: FALSTAFF
linegroup.line: Ay, that there was, mine host; one that hath taught
me more wit than ever I learned before in my life;
and I paid nothing for it neither, but was paid for
my learning.

linegroup.speaker: BARDOLPH
linegroup.line: Out, alas, sir! cozenage, mere cozenage!

linegroup.speaker: Host
linegroup.line: Where be my horses? speak well of them, varletto.

linegroup.speaker: BARDOLPH
linegroup.line: Run away with the cozeners; for so soon as I came
beyond Eton, they threw me off from behind one of
them, in a slough of mire; and set spurs and away,
like three German devils, three Doctor Faustuses.

linegroup.speaker: Host
linegroup.line: They are gone but to meet the duke, villain: do not
say they be fled; Germans are honest men.

linegroup.speaker: SIR HUGH EVANS
linegroup.line: Where is mine host?

linegroup.speaker: Host
linegroup.line: What is the matter, sir?

linegroup.speaker: SIR HUGH EVANS
linegroup.line: Have a care of your entertainments: there is a
friend of mine come to town tells me there is three
cozen-germans that has cozened all the hosts of
Readins, of Maidenhead, of Colebrook, of horses and
money. I tell you for good will, look you: you
are wise and full of gibes and vlouting-stocks, and
'tis not convenient you should be cozened. Fare you well.

linegroup.speaker: DOCTOR CAIUS
linegroup.line: Vere is mine host de Jarteer?

linegroup.speaker: Host
linegroup.line: Here, master doctor, in perplexity and doubtful dilemma.

linegroup.speaker: DOCTOR CAIUS
linegroup.line: I cannot tell vat is dat: but it is tell-a me dat
you make grand preparation for a duke de Jamany: by
my trot, dere is no duke dat the court is know to
come. I tell you for good vill: adieu.

linegroup.speaker: Host
linegroup.line: Hue and cry, villain, go! Assist me, knight. I am
undone! Fly, run, hue and cry, villain! I am undone!

linegroup.speaker: FALSTAFF
linegroup.line: I would all the world might be cozened; for I have
been cozened and beaten too. If it should come to
the ear of the court, how I have been transformed
and how my transformation hath been washed and
cudgelled, they would melt me out of my fat drop by
drop and liquor fishermen's boots with me; I warrant
they would whip me with their fine wits till I were
as crest-fallen as a dried pear. I never prospered
since I forswore myself at primero. Well, if my
wind were but long enough to say my prayers, I would repent.
Now, whence come you?

linegroup.speaker: MISTRESS QUICKLY
linegroup.line: From the two parties, forsooth.

linegroup.speaker: FALSTAFF
linegroup.line: The devil take one party and his dam the other! and
so they shall be both bestowed. I have suffered more
for their sakes, more than the villanous inconstancy
of man's disposition is able to bear.

linegroup.speaker: MISTRESS QUICKLY
linegroup.line: And have not they suffered? Yes, I warrant;
speciously one of them; Mistress Ford, good heart,
is beaten black and blue, that you cannot see a
white spot about her.

linegroup.speaker: FALSTAFF
linegroup.line: What tellest thou me of black and blue? I was
beaten myself into all the colours of the rainbow;
and I was like to be apprehended for the witch of
Brentford: but that my admirable dexterity of wit,
my counterfeiting the action of an old woman,
delivered me, the knave constable had set me i' the
stocks, i' the common stocks, for a witch.

linegroup.speaker: MISTRESS QUICKLY
linegroup.line: Sir, let me speak with you in your chamber: you
shall hear how things go; and, I warrant, to your
content. Here is a letter will say somewhat. Good
hearts, what ado here is to bring you together!
Sure, one of you does not serve heaven well, that
you are so crossed.

linegroup.speaker: FALSTAFF
linegroup.line: Come up into my chamber.

section.title: SCENE VI. Another room in the Garter Inn.

linegroup.speaker: Host
linegroup.line: Master Fenton, talk not to me; my mind is heavy: I
will give over all.

linegroup.speaker: FENTON
linegroup.line: Yet hear me speak. Assist me in my purpose,
And, as I am a gentleman, I'll give thee
A hundred pound in gold more than your loss.

linegroup.speaker: Host
linegroup.line: I will hear you, Master Fenton; and I will at the
least keep your counsel.

linegroup.speaker: FENTON
linegroup.line: From time to time I have acquainted you
With the dear love I bear to fair Anne Page;
Who mutually hath answer'd my affection,
So far forth as herself might be her chooser,
Even to my wish: I have a letter from her
Of such contents as you will wonder at;
The mirth whereof so larded with my matter,
That neither singly can be manifested,
Without the show of both; fat Falstaff
Hath a great scene: the image of the jest
I'll show you here at large. Hark, good mine host.
To-night at Herne's oak, just 'twixt twelve and one,
Must my sweet Nan present the Fairy Queen;
The purpose why, is here: in which disguise,
While other jests are something rank on foot,
Her father hath commanded her to slip
Away with Slender and with him at Eton
Immediately to marry: she hath consented: Now, sir,
Her mother, ever strong against that match
And firm for Doctor Caius, hath appointed
That he shall likewise shuffle her away,
While other sports are tasking of their minds,
And at the deanery, where a priest attends,
Straight marry her: to this her mother's plot
She seemingly obedient likewise hath
Made promise to the doctor. Now, thus it rests:
Her father means she shall be all in white,
And in that habit, when Slender sees his time
To take her by the hand and bid her go,
She shall go with him: her mother hath intended,
The better to denote her to the doctor,
For they must all be mask'd and vizarded,
That quaint in green she shall be loose enrobed,
With ribands pendent, flaring 'bout her head;
And when the doctor spies his vantage ripe,
To pinch her by the hand, and, on that token,
The maid hath given consent to go with him.

linegroup.speaker: Host
linegroup.line: Which means she to deceive, father or mother?

linegroup.speaker: FENTON
linegroup.line: Both, my good host, to go along with me:
And here it rests, that you'll procure the vicar
To stay for me at church 'twixt twelve and one,
And, in the lawful name of marrying,
To give our hearts united ceremony.

linegroup.speaker: Host
linegroup.line: Well, husband your device; I'll to the vicar:
Bring you the maid, you shall not lack a priest.

linegroup.speaker: FENTON
linegroup.line: So shall I evermore be bound to thee;
Besides, I'll make a present recompense.

section.title: SCENE I. A room in the Garter Inn.

linegroup.speaker: FALSTAFF
linegroup.line: Prithee, no more prattling; go. I'll hold. This is
the third time; I hope good luck lies in odd
numbers. Away I go. They say there is divinity in
odd numbers, either in nativity, chance, or death. Away!

linegroup.speaker: MISTRESS QUICKLY
linegroup.line: I'll provide you a chain; and I'll do what I can to
get you a pair of horns.

linegroup.speaker: FALSTAFF
linegroup.line: Away, I say; time wears: hold up your head, and mince.
How now, Master Brook! Master Brook, the matter
will be known to-night, or never. Be you in the
Park about midnight, at Herne's oak, and you shall
see wonders.

linegroup.speaker: FORD
linegroup.line: Went you not to her yesterday, sir, as you told me
you had appointed?

linegroup.speaker: FALSTAFF
linegroup.line: I went to her, Master Brook, as you see, like a poor
old man: but I came from her, Master Brook, like a
poor old woman. That same knave Ford, her husband,
hath the finest mad devil of jealousy in him,
Master Brook, that ever governed frenzy. I will tell
you: he beat me grievously, in the shape of a
woman; for in the shape of man, Master Brook, I fear
not Goliath with a weaver's beam; because I know
also life is a shuttle. I am in haste; go along
with me: I'll tell you all, Master Brook. Since I
plucked geese, played truant and whipped top, I knew
not what 'twas to be beaten till lately. Follow
me: I'll tell you strange things of this knave
Ford, on whom to-night I will be revenged, and I
will deliver his wife into your hand. Follow.
Strange things in hand, Master Brook! Follow.

section.title: SCENE II. Windsor Park.

linegroup.speaker: PAGE
linegroup.line: Come, come; we'll couch i' the castle-ditch till we
see the light of our fairies. Remember, son Slender,
my daughter.

linegroup.speaker: SLENDER
linegroup.line: Ay, forsooth; I have spoke with her and we have a
nay-word how to know one another: I come to her in
white, and cry 'mum;' she cries 'budget;' and by
that we know one another.

linegroup.speaker: SHALLOW
linegroup.line: That's good too: but what needs either your 'mum'
or her 'budget?' the white will decipher her well
enough. It hath struck ten o'clock.

linegroup.speaker: PAGE
linegroup.line: The night is dark; light and spirits will become it
well. Heaven prosper our sport! No man means evil
but the devil, and we shall know him by his horns.
Let's away; follow me.

section.title: SCENE III. A street leading to the Park.
section.para: Enter MISTRESS PAGE, MISTRESS FORD, and DOCTOR CAIUS

linegroup.speaker: MISTRESS PAGE
linegroup.line: Master doctor, my daughter is in green: when you
see your time, take her by the band, away with her
to the deanery, and dispatch it quickly. Go before
into the Park: we two must go together.

linegroup.speaker: DOCTOR CAIUS
linegroup.line: I know vat I have to do. Adieu.

linegroup.speaker: MISTRESS PAGE
linegroup.line: Fare you well, sir.
My husband will not rejoice so much at the abuse of
Falstaff as he will chafe at the doctor's marrying
my daughter: but 'tis no matter; better a little
chiding than a great deal of heart-break.

linegroup.speaker: MISTRESS FORD
linegroup.line: Where is Nan now and her troop of fairies, and the
Welsh devil Hugh?

linegroup.speaker: MISTRESS PAGE
linegroup.line: They are all couched in a pit hard by Herne's oak,
with obscured lights; which, at the very instant of
Falstaff's and our meeting, they will at once
display to the night.

linegroup.speaker: MISTRESS FORD
linegroup.line: That cannot choose but amaze him.

linegroup.speaker: MISTRESS PAGE
linegroup.line: If he be not amazed, he will be mocked; if he be
amazed, he will every way be mocked.

linegroup.speaker: MISTRESS FORD
linegroup.line: We'll betray him finely.

linegroup.speaker: MISTRESS PAGE
linegroup.line: Against such lewdsters and their lechery
Those that betray them do no treachery.

linegroup.speaker: MISTRESS FORD
linegroup.line: The hour draws on. To the oak, to the oak!

section.title: SCENE IV. Windsor Park.
section.para: Enter SIR HUGH EVANS, disguised, with others as Fairies

linegroup.speaker: SIR HUGH EVANS
linegroup.line: Trib, trib, fairies; come; and remember your parts:
be pold, I pray you; follow me into the pit; and
when I give the watch-'ords, do as I pid you:
come, come; trib, trib.

section.title: SCENE V. Another part of the Park.

linegroup.speaker: FALSTAFF
linegroup.line: The Windsor bell hath struck twelve; the minute
draws on. Now, the hot-blooded gods assist me!
Remember, Jove, thou wast a bull for thy Europa; love
set on thy horns. O powerful love! that, in some
respects, makes a beast a man, in some other, a man
a beast. You were also, Jupiter, a swan for the love
of Leda. O omnipotent Love! how near the god drew
to the complexion of a goose! A fault done first in
the form of a beast. O Jove, a beastly fault! And
then another fault in the semblance of a fowl; think
on 't, Jove; a foul fault! When gods have hot
backs, what shall poor men do? For me, I am here a
Windsor stag; and the fattest, I think, i' the
forest. Send me a cool rut-time, Jove, or who can
blame me to piss my tallow? Who comes here? my
doe?

section.para: Enter MISTRESS FORD and MISTRESS PAGE

linegroup.speaker: MISTRESS FORD
linegroup.line: Sir John! art thou there, my deer? my male deer?

linegroup.speaker: FALSTAFF
linegroup.line: My doe with the black scut! Let the sky rain
potatoes; let it thunder to the tune of Green
Sleeves, hail kissing-comfits and snow eringoes; let
there come a tempest of provocation, I will shelter me here.

linegroup.speaker: MISTRESS FORD
linegroup.line: Mistress Page is come with me, sweetheart.

linegroup.speaker: FALSTAFF
linegroup.line: Divide me like a bribe buck, each a haunch: I will
keep my sides to myself, my shoulders for the fellow
of this walk, and my horns I bequeath your husbands.
Am I a woodman, ha? Speak I like Herne the hunter?
Why, now is Cupid a child of conscience; he makes
restitution. As I am a true spirit, welcome!

linegroup.speaker: MISTRESS PAGE
linegroup.line: Alas, what noise?

linegroup.speaker: MISTRESS FORD
linegroup.line: Heaven forgive our sins

linegroup.speaker: FALSTAFF
linegroup.line: What should this be?

linegroup.speaker: MISTRESS FORD
MISTRESS PAGE
linegroup.line: Away, away!

linegroup.speaker: FALSTAFF
linegroup.line: I think the devil will not have me damned, lest the
oil that's in me should set hell on fire; he would
never else cross me thus.

section.para: Enter SIR HUGH EVANS, disguised as before; PISTOL, as Hobgoblin; MISTRESS QUICKLY, ANNE PAGE, and others, as Fairies, with tapers

linegroup.speaker: MISTRESS QUICKLY
linegroup.line: Fairies, black, grey, green, and white,
You moonshine revellers and shades of night,
You orphan heirs of fixed destiny,
Attend your office and your quality.
Crier Hobgoblin, make the fairy oyes.

linegroup.speaker: PISTOL
linegroup.line: Elves, list your names; silence, you airy toys.
Cricket, to Windsor chimneys shalt thou leap:
Where fires thou find'st unraked and hearths unswept,
There pinch the maids as blue as bilberry:
Our radiant queen hates sluts and sluttery.

linegroup.speaker: FALSTAFF
linegroup.line: They are fairies; he that speaks to them shall die:
I'll wink and couch: no man their works must eye.

linegroup.speaker: SIR HUGH EVANS
linegroup.line: Where's Bede? Go you, and where you find a maid
That, ere she sleep, has thrice her prayers said,
Raise up the organs of her fantasy;
Sleep she as sound as careless infancy:
But those as sleep and think not on their sins,
Pinch them, arms, legs, backs, shoulders, sides and shins.

linegroup.speaker: MISTRESS QUICKLY
linegroup.line: About, about;
Search Windsor Castle, elves, within and out:
Strew good luck, ouphes, on every sacred room:
That it may stand till the perpetual doom,
In state as wholesome as in state 'tis fit,
Worthy the owner, and the owner it.
The several chairs of order look you scour
With juice of balm and every precious flower:
Each fair instalment, coat, and several crest,
With loyal blazon, evermore be blest!
And nightly, meadow-fairies, look you sing,
Like to the Garter's compass, in a ring:
The expressure that it bears, green let it be,
More fertile-fresh than all the field to see;
And 'Honi soit qui mal y pense' write
In emerald tufts, flowers purple, blue and white;
Let sapphire, pearl and rich embroidery,
Buckled below fair knighthood's bending knee:
Fairies use flowers for their charactery.
Away; disperse: but till 'tis one o'clock,
Our dance of custom round about the oak
Of Herne the hunter, let us not forget.

linegroup.speaker: SIR HUGH EVANS
linegroup.line: Pray you, lock hand in hand; yourselves in order set
And twenty glow-worms shall our lanterns be,
To guide our measure round about the tree.
But, stay; I smell a man of middle-earth.

linegroup.speaker: FALSTAFF
linegroup.line: Heavens defend me from that Welsh fairy, lest he
transform me to a piece of cheese!

linegroup.speaker: PISTOL
linegroup.line: Vile worm, thou wast o'erlook'd even in thy birth.

linegroup.speaker: MISTRESS QUICKLY
linegroup.line: With trial-fire touch me his finger-end:
If he be chaste, the flame will back descend
And turn him to no pain; but if he start,
It is the flesh of a corrupted heart.

linegroup.speaker: PISTOL
linegroup.line: A trial, come.

linegroup.speaker: SIR HUGH EVANS
linegroup.line: Come, will this wood take fire?

section.para: They burn him with their tapers

linegroup.speaker: FALSTAFF
linegroup.line: Oh, Oh, Oh!

linegroup.speaker: MISTRESS QUICKLY
linegroup.line: Corrupt, corrupt, and tainted in desire!
About him, fairies; sing a scornful rhyme;
And, as you trip, still pinch him to your time.
Fie on sinful fantasy!
Fie on lust and luxury!
Lust is but a bloody fire,
Kindled with unchaste desire,
Fed in heart, whose flames aspire
As thoughts do blow them, higher and higher.
Pinch him, fairies, mutually;
Pinch him for his villany;
Pinch him, and burn him, and turn him about,
Till candles and starlight and moonshine be out.

section.para: During this song they pinch FALSTAFF. DOCTOR CAIUS comes one way, and steals away a boy in green; SLENDER another way, and takes off a boy in white; and FENTON comes and steals away ANN PAGE. A noise of hunting is heard within. All the Fairies run away. FALSTAFF pulls off his buck's head, and rises
Enter PAGE, FORD, MISTRESS PAGE, and MISTRESS FORD

linegroup.speaker: PAGE
linegroup.line: Nay, do not fly; I think we have watch'd you now
Will none but Herne the hunter serve your turn?

linegroup.speaker: MISTRESS PAGE
linegroup.line: I pray you, come, hold up the jest no higher
Now, good Sir John, how like you Windsor wives?
See you these, husband? do not these fair yokes
Become the forest better than the town?

linegroup.speaker: FORD
linegroup.line: Now, sir, who's a cuckold now? Master Brook,
Falstaff's a knave, a cuckoldly knave; here are his
horns, Master Brook: and, Master Brook, he hath
enjoyed nothing of Ford's but his buck-basket, his
cudgel, and twenty pounds of money, which must be
paid to Master Brook; his horses are arrested for
it, Master Brook.

linegroup.speaker: MISTRESS FORD
linegroup.line: Sir John, we have had ill luck; we could never meet.
I will never take you for my love again; but I will
always count you my deer.

linegroup.speaker: FALSTAFF
linegroup.line: I do begin to perceive that I am made an ass.

linegroup.speaker: FORD
linegroup.line: Ay, and an ox too: both the proofs are extant.

linegroup.speaker: FALSTAFF
linegroup.line: And these are not fairies? I was three or four
times in the thought they were not fairies: and yet
the guiltiness of my mind, the sudden surprise of my
powers, drove the grossness of the foppery into a
received belief, in despite of the teeth of all
rhyme and reason, that they were fairies. See now
how wit may be made a Jack-a-Lent, when 'tis upon
ill employment!

linegroup.speaker: SIR HUGH EVANS
linegroup.line: Sir John Falstaff, serve Got, and leave your
desires, and fairies will not pinse you.

linegroup.speaker: FORD
linegroup.line: Well said, fairy Hugh.

linegroup.speaker: SIR HUGH EVANS
linegroup.line: And leave your jealousies too, I pray you.

linegroup.speaker: FORD
linegroup.line: I will never mistrust my wife again till thou art
able to woo her in good English.

linegroup.speaker: FALSTAFF
linegroup.line: Have I laid my brain in the sun and dried it, that
it wants matter to prevent so gross o'erreaching as
this? Am I ridden with a Welsh goat too? shall I
have a coxcomb of frize? 'Tis time I were choked
with a piece of toasted cheese.

linegroup.speaker: SIR HUGH EVANS
linegroup.line: Seese is not good to give putter; your belly is all putter.

linegroup.speaker: FALSTAFF
linegroup.line: 'Seese' and 'putter'! have I lived to stand at the
taunt of one that makes fritters of English? This
is enough to be the decay of lust and late-walking
through the realm.

linegroup.speaker: MISTRESS PAGE
linegroup.line: Why Sir John, do you think, though we would have the
virtue out of our hearts by the head and shoulders
and have given ourselves without scruple to hell,
that ever the devil could have made you our delight?

linegroup.speaker: FORD
linegroup.line: What, a hodge-pudding? a bag of flax?

linegroup.speaker: MISTRESS PAGE
linegroup.line: A puffed man?

linegroup.speaker: PAGE
linegroup.line: Old, cold, withered and of intolerable entrails?

linegroup.speaker: FORD
linegroup.line: And one that is as slanderous as Satan?

linegroup.speaker: PAGE
linegroup.line: And as poor as Job?

linegroup.speaker: FORD
linegroup.line: And as wicked as his wife?

linegroup.speaker: SIR HUGH EVANS
linegroup.line: And given to fornications, and to taverns and sack
and wine and metheglins, and to drinkings and
swearings and starings, pribbles and prabbles?

linegroup.speaker: FALSTAFF
linegroup.line: Well, I am your theme: you have the start of me; I
am dejected; I am not able to answer the Welsh
flannel; ignorance itself is a plummet o'er me: use
me as you will.

linegroup.speaker: FORD
linegroup.line: Marry, sir, we'll bring you to Windsor, to one
Master Brook, that you have cozened of money, to
whom you should have been a pander: over and above
that you have suffered, I think to repay that money
will be a biting affliction.

linegroup.speaker: PAGE
linegroup.line: Yet be cheerful, knight: thou shalt eat a posset
to-night at my house; where I will desire thee to
laugh at my wife, that now laughs at thee: tell her
Master Slender hath married her daughter.

linegroup.speaker: MISTRESS PAGE
linegroup.line: Aside Doctors doubt that: if Anne Page be my
daughter, she is, by this, Doctor Caius' wife.

linegroup.speaker: SLENDER
linegroup.line: Whoa ho! ho, father Page!

linegroup.speaker: PAGE
linegroup.line: Son, how now! how now, son! have you dispatched?

linegroup.speaker: SLENDER
linegroup.line: Dispatched! I'll make the best in Gloucestershire
know on't; would I were hanged, la, else.

linegroup.speaker: PAGE
linegroup.line: Of what, son?

linegroup.speaker: SLENDER
linegroup.line: I came yonder at Eton to marry Mistress Anne Page,
and she's a great lubberly boy. If it had not been
i' the church, I would have swinged him, or he
should have swinged me. If I did not think it had
been Anne Page, would I might never stir!--and 'tis
a postmaster's boy.

linegroup.speaker: PAGE
linegroup.line: Upon my life, then, you took the wrong.

linegroup.speaker: SLENDER
linegroup.line: What need you tell me that? I think so, when I took
a boy for a girl. If I had been married to him, for
all he was in woman's apparel, I would not have had
him.

linegroup.speaker: PAGE
linegroup.line: Why, this is your own folly. Did not I tell you how
you should know my daughter by her garments?

linegroup.speaker: SLENDER
linegroup.line: I went to her in white, and cried 'mum,' and she
cried 'budget,' as Anne and I had appointed; and yet
it was not Anne, but a postmaster's boy.

linegroup.speaker: MISTRESS PAGE
linegroup.line: Good George, be not angry: I knew of your purpose;
turned my daughter into green; and, indeed, she is
now with the doctor at the deanery, and there married.

linegroup.speaker: DOCTOR CAIUS
linegroup.line: Vere is Mistress Page? By gar, I am cozened: I ha'
married un garcon, a boy; un paysan, by gar, a boy;
it is not Anne Page: by gar, I am cozened.

linegroup.speaker: MISTRESS PAGE
linegroup.line: Why, did you take her in green?

linegroup.speaker: DOCTOR CAIUS
linegroup.line: Ay, by gar, and 'tis a boy: by gar, I'll raise all Windsor.

linegroup.speaker: FORD
linegroup.line: This is strange. Who hath got the right Anne?

linegroup.speaker: PAGE
linegroup.line: My heart misgives me: here comes Master Fenton.
How now, Master Fenton!

linegroup.speaker: ANNE PAGE
linegroup.line: Pardon, good father! good my mother, pardon!

linegroup.speaker: PAGE
linegroup.line: Now, mistress, how chance you went not with Master Slender?

linegroup.speaker: MISTRESS PAGE
linegroup.line: Why went you not with master doctor, maid?

linegroup.speaker: FENTON
linegroup.line: You do amaze her: hear the truth of it.
You would have married her most shamefully,
Where there was no proportion held in love.
The truth is, she and I, long since contracted,
Are now so sure that nothing can dissolve us.
The offence is holy that she hath committed;
And this deceit loses the name of craft,
Of disobedience, or unduteous title,
Since therein she doth evitate and shun
A thousand irreligious cursed hours,
Which forced marriage would have brought upon her.

linegroup.speaker: FORD
linegroup.line: Stand not amazed; here is no remedy:
In love the heavens themselves do guide the state;
Money buys lands, and wives are sold by fate.

linegroup.speaker: FALSTAFF
linegroup.line: I am glad, though you have ta'en a special stand to
strike at me, that your arrow hath glanced.

linegroup.speaker: PAGE
linegroup.line: Well, what remedy? Fenton, heaven give thee joy!
What cannot be eschew'd must be embraced.

linegroup.speaker: FALSTAFF
linegroup.line: When night-dogs run, all sorts of deer are chased.

linegroup.speaker: MISTRESS PAGE
linegroup.line: Well, I will muse no further. Master Fenton,
Heaven give you many, many merry days!
Good husband, let us every one go home,
And laugh this sport o'er by a country fire;
Sir John and all.

linegroup.speaker: FORD
linegroup.line: Let it be so. Sir John,
To Master Brook you yet shall hold your word
For he tonight shall lie with Mistress Ford.
